importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the incident was reported and updated in the article, indicating the current status of the investigation and public awareness.
The date when the flight incident occurred, with the emergency landing taking place on Thursday, October 22, 2025.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The altitude range where WindBorne's balloons are now being monitored and adjusted to reduce collision risks with aircraft.

keyTakeAways: A weather balloon, possibly from WindBorne, may have struck the cockpit window of United Flight 1093, causing a crack and injuring a pilot.
The flight, operating from Denver to Los Angeles, safely diverted to Salt Lake City after declaring an emergency due to the incident.
The first officer sustained minor injuries and was treated upon landing.
WindBorne has acknowledged the incident and is cooperating with the NTSB and FAA to investigate the cause and prevent future occurrences.

WindBorne has implemented immediate operational changes, including adjusting balloon deployment timing between 30,000 and 40,000 feet, and is developing autonomous flight avoidance systems and improved balloon hardware to reduce impact forces.
The aircraft was later flown to Rockford, Illinois, for maintenance at United Airlines' 737 maintenance facility.

namedEntities.name: United Airlines

namedEntities.name: 40,000 feet

summaryOfNewsArticle: A United Airlines Boeing 737 flight (Flight 1093) traveling from Denver to Los Angeles experienced a cockpit window breach that injured a pilot, leading to an emergency landing in Salt Lake City. The company behind the incident, WindBorne, a California-based weather balloon startup, has acknowledged the possibility that one of its balloons struck the plane. WindBorne is cooperating with the NTSB and FAA to investigate and has already implemented operational changes, such as altering balloon deployment between 30,000 and 40,000 feet, and is developing autonomous systems and improved balloon designs to reduce collision risks. The aircraft was later flown to Rockford, Illinois, for maintenance.
